headline.sub: State Fiscal Problems Expected to Worsen;
headline.print_headline: States Have Not Yet Seen the Worst of Economic Times, Governors at Meeting Say
headline.main: States Have Not Yet Seen the Worst of Economic Times, Governors at Meeting Say

docs.lead_paragraph: Although the national economy has begun to bounce back, governors said that the worst had yet to come at the state level, where revenues are still falling short of projections.
docs.snippet: Although the national economy has begun to bounce back, governors said that the worst had yet to come at the state level, where revenues are still falling short of projections.

docs.abstract: The president holds a town hall meeting out West, while conservatives convene back in Washington.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama finishes off his swing out West today, holding a town hall meeting and giving a speech to the Chamber of Commerce in Nevada.

headline.main: The Care and Feeding of Kids: Finding Information on Nutrition and Fitness

byline.original: By CATHERINE HUTCHINGS and HOLLY EPSTEIN OJALVO

docs.abstract: Lesson Plan | Exploring news and facts about teen health and childhood obesity.
docs.lead_paragraph: Overview | How healthy are children in America? Why did first lady Michelle Obama introduce a new health initiative aimed at reducing childhood obesity? In this lesson, students reflect on their knowledge of health, nutrition and exercise. Then they review New York Times articles, videos and other features on issues related to children's health and diet, either by playing a "bingo" game or by running through the issues from A to Z. Finally, students create a personalized calendar to encourage them to make healthy choices.
docs.snippet: Lesson Plan | Exploring news and facts about teen health and childhood obesity.

headline.main: Should Coke Talk About Heart Health?

docs.abstract: Soft drink makers increasingly are being accused of contributing to the nation's obesity epidemic. Now a consumer advocacy group is questioning whether Coca-Cola should be allowed to sponsor a national heart health campaign.
docs.lead_paragraph: Soft drink makers increasingly are being accused of contributing to the nation's obesity epidemic. Now a consumer advocacy group is questioning whether Coca-Cola should be allowed to sponsor a national heart health campaign.
docs.snippet: Soft drink makers increasingly are being accused of contributing to the nation's obesity epidemic. Now a consumer advocacy group is questioning whether Coca-Cola should be allowed to sponsor a national heart health campaign.

headline.seo: From Title IX, Evidence of Sports’ Lasting Effects
headline.print_headline: As Girls Become Women, Sports Pay Dividends

headline.seo: Debating the Unknowns in Obesity Surgery for Children
headline.print_headline: A Debate On Gastric Surgery For Youths

docs.lead_paragraph: Though still considered experimental, bariatric surgery is fast becoming the next front in the battle against pediatric obesity.

headline.main: As Girls Become Women, Sports Pay Dividends

docs.abstract: Two new studies found that girls' involvement in team sports can mean lifelong improvements in educational, work and health prospects.
docs.lead_paragraph: Almost four decades after the federal education law called Title IX opened the door for girls to participate in high school and college athletics, a crucial question has remained unanswered: Do sports make a long-term difference in a woman's life?
docs.snippet: Two new studies found that girls' involvement in team sports can mean lifelong improvements in educational, work and health prospects.

docs.abstract: Why leasing a car is becoming more attractive again, why lenders should reduce loan balances and other consumer-focused items from Monday's Times.
docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
